title: Bridestones Walking Route

images.title: Gordon Hatton / Low Bridestones, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Low Bridestones. A series of wind eroded sandstone rocks perched along the edge of Bridestone Griff and Dinsdale Griff on National Trust land.

images.title: Andrew / Bridestones Todmorden, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridestones Todmorden. A good example of free face retreat. Which has produced these fine specimens of gritstone tors.

images.title: David Hillas / The Pepperpot on Bridestones Moor, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Pepperpot on Bridestones Moor

images.title: Kevin Rushton / Bridestones Moor, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridestones Moor. Triangulation Pillar No S4501.The moor is most famous for its peculiar shaped rock formations formed under the sea 150 million years ago

images.title: Jim Champion / The High Bridestones, Sleights Moor, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The High Bridestones, Sleights Moor. On the left is the tallest of the intact standing stones at the High Bridestones site on Sleights Moor. There are several fallen megaliths nearby, and others scattered around the area. A little further to the north-west is another set of standing stones known as the Low Bridestones. There are some more famous High and Low Bridestones elsewhere in the North York Moors national park, in gridsquare SE8791 - however those Bridestones are natural rock formations. The locally popular name of "Bridestones" may come from the Norse for being on the brink (edge). There are local legends that explain the stones as petrified bridal parties lost in the mists that hang on the moors. For some reason other visitors have felt the need to hammer coins into the natural cracks in the tallest standing stone.

images.title: Hugh Chappell / Low Bridestones, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Low Bridestones.The most southerly of the Low Bridestones - A National Trust property.

description: Visit these fascinating sandstone sculptures on this splendid walk in Dalby Forest. The geologically significant area dates back to the Jurassic period 150 million years ago. The Bridestones is a nature reserve with good footpaths taking you around the rocks to woodland and meadows with fabulous views from the reserve's elevated position. The area is run by the National Trust so there is a car park off Dalby Forest Drive near Staindale Lake and Adderstone Wood. From here you can pick up the walking trails taking you up to the stones. It's great in the summer with lots of wildflowers, heather, butterflies and birds to look out for. There are good options for extending your walk. You can pick up the footpath along the Staindale Beck or around Staindale Lake. The wider area of Dalby Forest has several different cycling and walking trails to try. A couple of miles to the west is the wonderful natural amphitheatre of the Hole of Horcum. There's more good trails to follow here through moorland and woodland. Langdale Forest is also just to the east. The Tabular Hills Walk long distance trail also runs past the site. You can follow it Dalby Forest and the Hole of Horcum.
